text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: outlieR R package automatic outlier detection using Isolation Forests (via isotree package). provides simple API automatic hyperparameter tuning, detailed feature-level diagnostics, comprehensive visualizations. Key features: - Single main function (detect_outliers()) use cases - Automatic hyperparameter tuning (grid, random, Bayesian search) - Per-feature outlier analysis using robust statistics - Rich visualization suite (score plots, PCA, feature importance, heatmaps) - data.table design efficient data processing - Support numeric categorical variables automatic one-hot encoding

title: CLAUDE.md
text: detect_outliers(): Primary function outlier detection get_outlier_summary(): Extract outlier information S3 methods: print.outlier_detector(), summary.outlier_detector() Returns outlier_detector S3 class containing model, scores, outliers, diagnostics prepare_data(): Handles column selection, type detection, one-hot encoding validate_inputs(): Input validation generate_outlier_details(): Creates per-observation feature-level analysis using robust z-scores (MAD-based) Automatic median imputation missing values tune_parameters(): Main tuning dispatcher tune_grid_search(): Grid search parameter combinations tune_random_search(): Random sampling hyperparameters tune_bayesian_optimization(): Placeholder (currently falls back random search) evaluate_params(): Uses Cohen’s d effect size measure outlier separation quality Supports parallel processing via parallel package S3 method: plot.outlier_detector() Plot types: “score”, “features”, “distribution”, “pca”, “heatmap”, “” Uses ggplot2 individual plots, patchwork combining multiple plots PCA plotting requires stored original data (datasets ≤10,000 rows) R/outlieR-package.R - Package documentation

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Uses testthat framework Test files mirror R/ structure: test-detect_outliers.R, test-preprocessing.R, test-tuning.R, test-visualization.R Tests use tune = FALSE default speed Located tests/testthat/

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Input validation (validate_inputs()) - checks data types, dimensions, parameter ranges Preprocessing (prepare_data()) - selects columns, encodes categoricals, imputes missing values Tuning (optional) - evaluates parameter combinations using parallel processing, ranks Cohen’s d Model training - builds isotree::isolation.forest optimized/specified parameters Scoring - computes anomaly scores (average path depth) Threshold determination - uses contamination parameter quantile-based threshold Detailed analysis - generates per-observation, per-feature diagnostics using MAD-based robust z-scores

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package computes detailed outlier information generate_outlier_details(): - observation, calculates robust z-scores feature using MAD (Median Absolute Deviation) - Identifies features z-score > 3 outlier features - Stores feature scores feat_score_<feature_name> columns - Computes n_outlier_features top_outlier_features outlier - Returns comprehensive data.table flexible downstream analysis

title: CLAUDE.md
text: data.table internally: Efficient operations, especially feature-level analysis data.frame compatibility: Accepts works data.frame data.table inputs Minimal storage: Original data stored datasets ≤10,000 rows (affects PCA plotting) Parallel default: Tuning uses parallel processing unless disabled Contamination-based thresholding: Uses quantile approach rather fixed threshold

title: CLAUDE.md
text: add new tuning algorithm: 1. Add function tune_<method>_search() R/tuning.R 2. Update tune_parameters() switch statement 3. Update detect_outliers() parameter documentation 4. Add tests tests/testthat/test-tuning.R

title: CLAUDE.md
text: add new plot type: 1. Create plot_<type>() helper function R/visualization.R 2. Add case plot.outlier_detector() switch statement 3. Update documentation examples 4. Add tests tests/testthat/test-visualization.R

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Feature-level analysis centralized generate_outlier_details(): - Uses MAD-based robust z-scores (less sensitive outliers standard deviation) - Z-score > 3 threshold identifying outlier features - Modify function change diagnostic logic package-wide

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Core dependencies: - isotree: Isolation forest implementation - data.table: Efficient data manipulation - cli: User-friendly console output - ggplot2: Visualization - parallel: Parallel processing tuning - patchwork: Combining multiple plots Suggested: - testthat: Testing framework

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Minimum 10 rows required analysis Contamination must 0 1 (exclusive) PCA plots require original data storage (datasets ≤10,000 rows) Bayesian optimization yet implemented (falls back random search) Categorical variables must convertible factors encoding Missing values imputed median (numeric )

title: Getting Started with outlieR
text: outlieR provides simple yet powerful interface automatic outlier detection tabular data. package leverages Isolation Forests via isotree package extends : Automatic hyperparameter tuning Detailed feature-level analysis Comprehensive visualizations data.table-based performance

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Development version from GitHub remotes::install_github("fabiandistler/outlieR")  # CRAN (once available) install.packages("outlieR") library(outlieR)

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Score distribution plot(result, type = "score") # Feature importance for outliers plot(result, type = "features") # Distribution of scores plot(result, type = "distribution") # PCA projection plot(result, type = "pca")

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Use only selected features result_subset <- detect_outliers(   data = iris,   target_cols = c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length"),   contamination = 0.05, # Expect 5% outliers   verbose = FALSE )  get_outlier_summary(result_subset, detailed = FALSE)

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code:
# Grid Search (systematic, all combinations) result_grid <- detect_outliers(   mtcars,   tune = TRUE,   tune_method = "grid",   parallel = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )  # Random Search (faster, good results) result_random <- detect_outliers(   mtcars,   tune = TRUE,   tune_method = "random",   parallel = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )  # Compare parameters cat("Grid Search Parameters:
") print(result_grid$params)  cat("
Random Search Parameters:
") print(result_random$params)

title: Getting Started with outlieR
text: maximum control, can disable tuning:
code: result_manual <- detect_outliers(   mtcars,   tune = FALSE,   n_trees = 200,   sample_size = 512,   max_depth = 12,   verbose = FALSE ) #> Warning in (function (data, sample_size = min(nrow(data), 10000L), ntrees = #> 500, : 'sample_size' is larger than the number of rows in 'data', will be #> decreased. #> Warning in (function (data, sample_size = min(nrow(data), 10000L), ntrees = #> 500, : Passed parameters for deterministic single-variable splits with no #> sub-sampling. Every tree fitted will end up doing exactly the same splits. It's #> recommended to set non-random split probabilities to less than 1, or to use the #> extended model (ndim > 1).  print(result_manual$params) #> $ntrees #> [1] 200 #>  #> $sample_size #> [1] 512 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 12 #>  #> $ndim #> [1] 1 #>  #> $ntry #> NULL

title: Getting Started with outlieR

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Function for quick quality check quality_check <- function(data, contamination = 0.05) {   result <- detect_outliers(     data,     contamination = contamination,     tune = FALSE, # Faster for quick check     verbose = FALSE   )    list(     n_outliers = sum(result$outliers),     pct_outliers = 100 * mean(result$outliers),     top_outliers = get_outlier_summary(result, detailed = FALSE)[1:5],     metrics = result$metrics   ) }  # Apply qc_result <- quality_check(mtcars) print(qc_result$top_outliers)

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code:
# Iteratively remove outliers and reassess iterative_cleaning <- function(data, max_iterations = 3, contamination = 0.1) {   clean_data <- data   removed_indices <- integer()    for (i in seq_len(max_iterations)) {     result <- detect_outliers(       clean_data,       contamination = contamination,       tune = FALSE,       verbose = FALSE     )      n_outliers <- sum(result$outliers)     if (n_outliers == 0) break      # Track indices in original dataset     outlier_rows <- which(result$outliers)     removed_indices <- c(removed_indices, outlier_rows)      # Remove outliers     clean_data <- clean_data[!result$outliers, ]      cat(sprintf("Iteration %d: %d outliers removed
", i, n_outliers))   }    list(     clean_data = clean_data,     removed_indices = removed_indices,     n_removed = length(removed_indices)   ) }  # Example (with small contamination value) cleaned <- iterative_cleaning(mtcars, contamination = 0.05) cat(sprintf("
Total removed: %d rows
", cleaned$n_removed))

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Which features are most frequently flagged as outliers? analyze_feature_outliers <- function(result) {   dt <- data.table::as.data.table(result$outlier_details)    # Extract feature score columns   score_cols <- grep("^feat_score_", names(dt), value = TRUE)    if (length(score_cols) == 0) {     return(NULL)   }    # For each feature: count observations with high score (>3)   feature_stats <- lapply(score_cols, function(col) {     col_clean <- gsub("^feat_score_", "", col)     scores <- dt[[col]]     data.table::data.table(       feature = col_clean,       n_high_score = sum(scores > 3, na.rm = TRUE),       mean_score = mean(scores, na.rm = TRUE),       max_score = max(scores, na.rm = TRUE)     )   })    feature_dt <- data.table::rbindlist(feature_stats)   feature_dt[order(-n_high_score)] }  result <- outlieR::detect_outliers(mtcars, verbose = FALSE) feature_analysis <- analyze_feature_outliers(result) utils::head(feature_analysis, 10)

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # For large data (>100k rows): result <- detect_outliers(   large_data,   tune = FALSE, # No tuning for speed   n_trees = 100, # Moderate number of trees   sample_size = 2048, # Larger samples   parallel = TRUE, # Parallel processing   verbose = TRUE # Progress tracking )

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Fast tuning with random search result <- detect_outliers(   data,   tune = TRUE,   tune_method = "random", # Faster than grid   parallel = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # For very large datasets: use data.table library(data.table) dt <- fread("large_file.csv") # Efficient loading  result <- detect_outliers(   dt,   target_cols = c("col1", "col2", "col3"), # Only relevant columns   tune = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )  # Original data is not stored in the result for >10k rows

title: Getting Started with outlieR
text: mean_score: Average anomaly score cohens_d: Effect size separation (>0.8 = strong) outlier_separation: Normalized separation outliers normal points detection_rate: Actual proportion detected outliers

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Check transaction data for suspicious patterns transactions <- fread("transactions.csv")  result <- detect_outliers(   transactions,   target_cols = c("amount", "frequency", "location_distance"),   contamination = 0.01, # Low for fraud (1%)   tune = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )  # Extract suspicious transactions for review suspicious <- get_outlier_summary(result) fwrite(suspicious, "suspicious_transactions.csv")

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Check IoT sensor readings sensor_data <- data.table::fread("sensor_readings.csv")  result <- detect_outliers(   sensor_data,   target_cols = c("temperature", "pressure", "humidity"),   contamination = 0.05,   tune = FALSE,   n_trees = 200 )  # Identify faulty readings faulty_readings <- sensor_data[result$outliers, ]

title: Getting Started with outlieR
code: # Find unusual customer behavior patterns customer_data <- data.table::fread("customer_behavior.csv")  result <- detect_outliers(   customer_data,   target_cols = c("purchase_frequency", "avg_order_value", "days_since_last"),   contamination = 0.10,   tune = TRUE,   tune_method = "random" )  # Identify VIP or risk customers unusual_customers <- customer_data[result$outliers, ]

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
text: outlieR provides simple, powerful API automatic outlier detection tabular data. package uses Isolation Forests (via isotree) automatic hyperparameter tuning delivers detailed feature-level diagnostics.

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
text: ✨ Simple API - One function use cases 🎯 Automatic Tuning - Grid Search, Random Search, Bayesian Optimization 📊 Detailed Diagnostics - Feature-level outlier analysis 📈 Comprehensive Visualizations - Score plots, feature importance, PCA projection 🔧 Flexible - Supports numeric categorical variables

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
code: # Grid Search (default, systematic but slower) result_grid <- detect_outliers(mtcars, tune_method = "grid")  # Random Search (faster, good results) result_random <- detect_outliers(mtcars, tune_method = "random")  # Bayesian Optimization (experimental) result_bayes <- detect_outliers(mtcars, tune_method = "bayesian")

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
code: # Automatic one-hot encoding of factors set.seed(42) data <- data.frame(   value1 = rnorm(100),   value2 = rnorm(100),   category = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 100, replace = TRUE) )  result <- detect_outliers(data)

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
code: result <- detect_outliers(mtcars)  # Which features are suspicious in row 31? detailed <- get_outlier_summary(result, detailed = TRUE) detailed[row_id == 31]

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
code: # Benchmark on different data sizes library(bench)  # Small dataset (1000 rows) small_data <- data.frame(matrix(rnorm(1000 * 10), ncol = 10)) mark(detect_outliers(small_data, tune = FALSE)) # ~500ms  # Medium dataset (10000 rows) medium_data <- data.frame(matrix(rnorm(10000 * 10), ncol = 10)) mark(detect_outliers(medium_data, tune = FALSE)) # ~2s  # With tuning (slower but better results) mark(detect_outliers(medium_data, tune = TRUE, tune_method = "random")) # ~20s (parallel on 4 cores)

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests
code: result <- detect_outliers(mtcars, contamination = 0.05)  # Use a custom threshold custom_threshold <- quantile(result$scores, 0.99) custom_outliers <- result$scores > custom_threshold  # Generate new details result$outliers <- custom_outliers result$threshold <- custom_threshold

title: outlieR: Automatic Outlier Detection Using Isolation Forests

title: Detect Outliers Using Isolation Forest — detect_outliers
text: data data.frame data.table containing data analyze target_cols Character vector column names analyze. NULL (default), numeric columns used contamination Numeric 0 1. Expected proportion outliers. Used automatic threshold determination. Default: 0.1 tune Logical. hyperparameters tuned? Default: TRUE tune_method Character. Tuning method: "grid", "random", "bayesian". Default: "grid" n_trees Integer. Number trees isolation forest. Default: 100 sample_size Integer "auto". Sample size tree. Default: "auto" max_depth Integer "auto". Maximum tree depth. Default: "auto" seed Integer. Random seed reproducibility. Default: NULL parallel Logical. Use parallel processing tuning? Default: TRUE verbose Logical. Print progress messages? Default: TRUE
